comments.commentBody:
Hello Bill,
As a student on an Ivy League campus, engaged in much of the campus activity surrounding this incident, I appreciate your thoughts here.

I'd appreciate it if you'd clarify a followup question I have to your comments—

The analysis of the greater power's responsibility to negotiate rather than retaliate strikes a very deep chord in many people 'fed up' with the situation and looking for tangible developments. I've heard my share of complaints regarding the "uncompromising" nature of the Israeli side.
How do you respond to that claim, while Hamas' charter and sworn purpose is the destruction of Israel? Can we really expect productive results if Hamas is determined to continue its pattern of hatred and violence? In other words, how can we expect to sit down "compromisingly" for peace with the current power in Gaza (naturally the West Bank gets involved in here)?
I think it's important to remember that the American/Israeli side is approaching the issue with a less ideological bent, despite Morsi's impressive "pragmatism" as the WH put it.

And Jordan Davies, please read the Hamas covenant which its leaders refuse to scrap.  They constantly reiterate their desire to make the land theirs from the Jordan to the Mediterranean.  You better believe them.

Jordan wrote: "The "right to exist" argument put forth by the Israelis is a very feeble excuse for them to use to attack Gaza."
Israel attacked Gaza because of the hundreds of rockets fired from it over the years, not because of the "right to exist" argument.

In order to stop an aggressor, the response must be disproportional. If an aggressor fires a rocket that just by pure luck lands in the open area, should the victim respond by firing a rocket into an open area or should it try to kill the firing squad and its commanders to avoid casualties next time when they become more skillful and get better rockets? It pains me to see death and suffering of ordinary palestinians and especially children, but it is hamas who puts them in the harms way by firing from the residential areas.

"Gaza’s grievances, particularly the border controls imposed by Israel that block the free movement of people and goods, will be addressed in talks starting 24 hours after the cease-fire begins."

Good.

Israel will talk to Hamas rather than continuing to use Hamas's refusal to recognize Israel's "right to exist" as a pretext for war.

Israel exists.

Hamas does not have to like that to talk to Israel and declare a truce, for 25 years say, in exchange for Israel's recognizing and respecting the human rights of the people in Gaza.

Like in all the places you mention
Hamas also has vowed to kill jews and destroy Isreal.
How do you handle a neighbor that wants to kill you
If you give them a chance.
I do not know the answer
Do you Adriana ?
Yes, shame on them for striking back. They should be used to being killed.

May be they have learned too much and therefore , are unable to refrain themselves from repeating the same on those whose ancestors lived side by side with their ancestors two thousand years ago!Truman will be remembered for two things with disdain by many----dropping of nukes on Hiroshima and Nagasaki and for planting them in Palestine/.

After Auschwitz, after Dachau, after Buchenwald, after Treblinka, after Belzec, after Majdanek, after Bergen-Belsen, after Ravensbruck, after Mauthausen...an entire ethnic-religious group who were persecuted, imprisoned, their possessions stripped, their land and homes taken have turned the tables and become the persecutor...apparently they learned their lessons with a tragically negative outcome instead of learning to never repeat such horrors again and instead of engaging in peace and compromise, they have persecuted, imprisoned, embargoed, walled in, and stolen homes and land, and killed many innocent lives in order to eradicate and remove a population that they don't agree with.  The behavior of Israel is disgusting and they should all be ashamed and think of their ancestors because this behavior is a betrayal of all the horrors that were endured.

FAT CHANCE of Hamas and the PA ever getting along. Although possibly Iran will lose enough of its confrontations with the rest of the world, including in Syria, that Hamas may end up having to deal with the PA. The possibility of the US destroying whomever is in its way over there one way or the other - directly, through proxies including Israel and maybe Egypt as well, or by simply washing its hands of the situation, allowing nature to take its course ( Israeli military destruction of the Palestinian "resistance", nuclear war between whomever is most provoked first and Iran) may clarify minds lol.
I'm just reading the comments and the same name keeps popping up defending Jackson. It's a little strange......
Not a month too soon. The people of his district deserved more respect from him than they got. I wish him well.
The pro-business side of their brains may be in control.
Obama and Mosi; an unlikely pair; are most likely to broker a deal.

WP it all sounds good, but I fear that Israel is still going to try to negotiate with stolen property and that will automatically end negotiations.

No amount of money is ever going to trump principles of justice in the muslim world.

That would be OK except that both sides are now controlled by extremes. The Palestinians by Hamas, who were democratically elected; and the extreme right in Israel by Netanyahu. They have both demonized the elected leader of Palestine and now they have to deal with Hamas.

The difficulty is that the people in charge on both sides are not engaging in good faith efforts to pursue peace. Until either the current leadership is persuaded that peace is in their best interest, or until such leadership is replaced with moderates who actually want a two-state solution, any agreements will be short lived.

My test for whether leaders are interested in peace is whether they follow the following three steps: (1) acknowledge that both sides, Israelis and Palestinians, have valid claims at stake - namely, the right to a country with security and economic freedom. (2) the blame game is pointless because there is more than enough blame to go around - illegal Israeli settlements and harsh policies towards the Palestinian people, Palestinian support (direct or tacit) of terrorism and denial of Israel's right to exist, too much violence by both sides. (3) work for a two state solution, based on 1967 borders with land swaps and shared access to Jerusalem; international security; and significant economic aid to rebuild Palestine.

The US should be using its significant financial aid to Israel, the Palestinians, and neighboring countries to get moderates who support these three points to the table, and to isolate the extremists on both sides who are acting in bad faith. And President Obama should prioritize getting a lasting peace agreement in his second term.

www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236
Fight back!  Make your gifts this year, or buy them from an American Artist or Craftsperson.

The Turkey Chronicles is a fitting description of the Republican primaries and of their vile comments made about Americans during the election campaign.

It's also an apt description of our over commercialization. In the earliest days, people demonstrated their significance as rugged individuals by bringing home the dinner from out in the wild.

Now retailers would have us believe we're demonstrating our rugged individualism if we come join their artificial hunt for bargains. We're supposed to feel clever and fulfilled if we can bring home a flat screen TV for a $50 savings. Of course, to feel that surge of rugged individualism, one must have a challenge. So crowds are hyped into a melee and stores play hide-and-seek with the bargains. It's The Hunger Games big-box retailer style as we eagerly fork over our money. Crass American Consumerism has it's Turkey Chronicles, too.

The best American Turkey Chronicles, however, are about how families come together once each year to share favorite foods, share smiles, discuss the past and hopes for the future, see how each has grown, and size up what needs to come next.

For me, in my heart, Thanksgiving has long been about FDR's Four Freedoms portrayed in paintings by Norman Rockwell: Freedom from Want, Freedom from Fear, Freedom of Speech, and Freedom of Religion. I have no trouble taking a moment to say quietly, "thank you," to a great people who struggle to maintain and extend those freedoms of the human spirit. Thank you.

I really don't know what to say.  That we are careening toward third-world status is not liberal scare-speak; it is, as this article seeks to illustrate, observable fact.  People need to grow up and realize that civilization doesn't happen for free, that we have to pay into it in good faith for it to work.
Real Brooklynites remain loyal to Brooklyn, no matter what.

It should be noted that Kidd's winning ways predated his tenure in the NBA. During his one year at Cal he (and Lamond Murray) led the Bears on one of their deepest runs in the the NCAA tourney, and before that led tiny St. Joseph's in Alameda to not one but two consecutive CA State championships. I was lucky enough to see him play several times in those years, and the only way to describe him was "a man among boys". His rebounding and hand strength were startling (he would routinely just take the ball out of opponents hands), as of course was his court vision.

As much as he is a good fit with the Knicks right now, its kind of a shame that he didn't get to finish off his career with the Warriors in front of his home town fans...
See my above post.
It is notable that Ohio, widely but incorrectly anticipated as the tipping point state, is the pinkest battleground state.  I call shenanigans.

I saw a few maps of voter preference, by county and even by polling place, and was amazed to see the lower Mississippi valley was all blue! Here in Memphis, a very blue city, I had no idea it extended southward so consistently but I guess it's the Black vote.

Ah, the Scarlet Knights on the banks of the Raritan. Rutgers is home to a great history department and a well named student union. I’m biased in regard to the history department as that’s where I did my graduate work. The student union naming took some demonstrating and negotiating. We marched to have it named after the greatest player and man to put on a Rutgers football jersey, Paul Robeson.

As many on this Forum probably know, football at Rutgers has a long history. In 1869 Rutgers played the very first intercollegiate football game against their instate nemesis, Princeton U.. I attended the Centennial replay of that game. The gridiron warriors in that historical replay (frat boys and volunteers, no scholarship recruits, all students first, last and always) were in period uniforms and helmets. They looked more Mad Max than Big 14.

So now Rutgers moves into the Big [9, 10, 11, 12, 13] 14, Bingo!$! Conference. Good luck, Knights. Hope you can pay off your debt, get out of athletics arms race and give those scholarships to history majors.

". . . The added income from playing in an elite conference with its own television network could not only reduce the reported $28 million annual subsidy the Rutgers athletic department receives from the university, . . ."
Not really relevant, but I have to say, I'm really enjoying the fact that republicans got so badly butthurt.
These are excellent points.  But I don't think we will be able to test them empirically unless there's alot of exit poll data detail out there that we don't know about.

With the post-election-night vote, Romney is now about 350,000 votes ahead of McCain, with perhaps 1-2 million votes still to come in.  Obama is about 5 million under Obama 2008, but at least 20-25small part of that will be 1 million NY/NJ votes, either late or lost to Sandy.
So you're saying Blasmaic, God rejected the GOP's policies too, not the the voters?

Is over performance for Obama just under-performance for Romney? Remember, Romney received 2 million votes less than John McCain in 2008-- so somebody didn't show up. Who? Conservatives in the deep South who always were reluctant about Romney but also may have been frightened of his minority religion. When a bunch of Romney people don't vote, that makes the Obama voters a greater percentage of the total -- and Obama out-performs his polling.

Also, look at Ohio and Pennsylvania, states where Romney lost, but did better than the 538 polling stew suggested that he should. Maybe the absent Romney voters in the deep South and the strong showing of Romney in Pennsylvania and Ohio is suggesting something more basic. If you offer them a Democrat and a Democrat, they'll choose a Democrat every time.

Ultimately though, it was the rally effect that swayed undecideds to Obama in the closing days that ended the Romney campaign. Whenever the country faces a crisis, people rally in support of the President even if only temporary. That bit of luck which changed the election outcome could explain why the Obama people have continued forward with their base-energizing rhetoric long after the GOP has conceded defeat with the Rice flap. I could never imagine a storm could be more costly than Hurricane Katrina, but a storm that re-elects a failed president to a second term surely could be yet.
Have a great Thanksgiving, Nate.
Well, he *won* it last time, and this time he didn't.  So how could he have outperformed 2008?
What's really important here in the election post-mortems is: Did that snake Joe What's His Name pay off the $2,000 wager that he supposedly had with Nate?
Yes, that was a great shout-out to Nate delivered by the president!

I wouldn't call a one point difference a significant overestimation; but still, I'd say the difference between Ohio and other places is that Obama didn't surprise everyone with his totals there. And the reason is probably that in Ohio, Obama won with a more "traditional" coalition of voters, as opposed to Florida, where his margins were pushed up by a lot of people who proved elusive to pollsters or were screened out by the LV profiles.

I have NO doubt about the answer -- voter suppression.

There are two reasons that I believe this. You cited one -- polls showed Obama would do as well in Ohio as he did in Iowa and Wisconsin and Nevada and better by a few points in Ohio than Virginia and Colorado. Yet, Obama did 2 to 3 percentage points better on Election Day than in the polls in all the states I mentioned except Ohio, where he did about 2 percentage points worse.

Point two -- look at the turnout figures that Nate Silver's chart showed the other day. The battleground states had MUCH higher turnout increases over 2008 than nonbattleground states and the states with the largest increases were states like Nevada, Wisconsin, Iowa and Colorado.

But turnout in Ohio (and Pennsylvania) was WAY down. Voters in Ohio waited on very long lines and voters in Pennsylvania were asked for their photo IDs although the state supreme court said the new law was voided.

And Florida was in the middle of the pack in increased voter turnout despite being No. 1 in voter population increase.
I'm waiting for someone to pop up with the urban legend about Tagg Romney and the Ohio voting machines.

I haven't seen much analysis of why the Ohio polls significantly overestimated Obama's vote total... as compared to other swing state polls that underestimated his support. Given that Ohio was polled with extraordinary frequency, I might assume that its polls would be more and not less accurate.

Thoughts?

Last time I checked, there were 16 states (none of them battlegrounds) in which the vote margin fell outside FiveThirtyEight's stated uncertainty. That seems like a lot. Nate, I hope you'll comment on this. What's the level of confidence of 538's stated uncertainties? Were they systematically under-estimated in non-battleground states and if so, why?
You are completely wrong. You need to visit the suburban counties, including DuPage and Lake. They are among the best educated counties in the nation and very high income. Not close to Alabama.

President O. did fine in the IL-17'th (upper western part of the state, including Rock Island, parts of Peoria and Rockford).  But yep; some of the southern parts and eastern parts (save Champaign county)....I'd have to agree.
The pink Illinois does not surprise me.  Illinois is Cook County surrounded by Alabama.

I think that there is less here than meets the eye. Look at the so-called battleground states: Florida, Ohio, Virginia, Wisconsin, Colorado, Iowa, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Minnesota, Michigan. All of these are rather pale; 3 are slightly red (pink), 9 are slightly blue.

This tells me: 538 was more accurate for these states because it had the most data for these. The others: polls were not nearly as numerous.
Mississippi has a very large African American population. A large swath of the state along the river is deep blue.

Any correlation with the racist states found in this paper? http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~sstephen/papers/RacialAnimusAndVoting...

Mississippi being bright blue seems like a glaring exception.
